stimulusHtml: The structural formulas of two compounds that are liquids at room temperature are shown above. Which of the following statements best explains the observation that compound 1 boils at 35°C, whereas its structural isomer, compound 2, boils at 118°C?
choicesHtml: Molecules of compound 1 have a linear shape and no net dipole, whereas molecules of compound 2 have a bent shape and are polar.
Molecules of compound 1 are bent less than molecules of compound 2; thus they have weaker dipole-dipole attractions.
There are dipole-dipole attractions among molecules of compound 1, whereas there are only dispersion forces among molecules of compound 2.
Although there are dipole-dipole attractions among molecules of both compound 1 and compound 2, the -OH group in compound 2 allows strong hydrogen bonding to occur.
